concern:
Not sure if anyone else feels this way but it can be a lonely journey in grad school especially because of the niche stresses, things we have to deal with. 

Created a group me that will hopefully foster some community for people to talk with one another and build some friendships or the very least camaraderie 

Hereâ€™s the link to join: You're invited to my new group 'Grad School Community' on GroupMe. Click here to join: https://groupme.com/join_group/86601776/iTupsbUn

dialogue_total.statement: Hi there! I'm glad you're here today. What's been on your mind lately?
Hey! Lately, I've just been feeling like grad school can get pretty isolating. It's been hard to find people who really get it, you know?
therapist: It sounds like you're feeling a bit alone in your experiences with grad school because it's hard to find others who truly understand. What's been the hardest part about this for you?
client: I think it's just the constant pressure and expectation. Like, everyone seems to be doing their own thing, and it's tough to connect over shared struggles.

Therapist: It seems like the pressure and expectations are really weighing on you, and it's challenging to connect with others who might be experiencing the same things. How does that affect how you feel day-to-day?
client: Honestly, it makes me feel pretty anxious and sometimes a bit overwhelmed. Some days I just feel like I'm trudging through, and I wish I had more people to talk to who understand the grind.

It sounds like the anxiety and feeling of being overwhelmed are really impacting your daily life. I wonder how connecting with others who understand the grad school experience might change things for you.
Yeah, I think connecting with others who are in the same boat could really help. Just having folks to share the ups and downs with would make the whole process feel more manageable and less lonely.

Therapist: That makes a lot of sense. Connecting with others could indeed provide support and reduce that sense of loneliness. Based on what you've shared, some options could include joining a study group, participating in grad school forums, or attending social events organized by your program. What do you think might be the most helpful first step for you?

Honestly, I think the GroupMe I set up could be a good start. It's a low-pressure way to meet people who are dealing with the same stuff without having to commit to in-person events right away. I'm hoping it'll help create a space where it doesn't feel weird to be open about struggling sometimes.
That sounds like a thoughtful choice, and it seems like the GroupMe could really serve as a supportive space. How do you plan to engage with the group to encourage that openness and connection?

I think I'll start by sharing some of my own experiences and feelings, you know, just to break the ice. It might help others feel comfortable opening up if they see someone else being real about what they're going through. Plus, I can ask questions to get conversations going and maybe set up some casual virtual meetups or study sessions.

It sounds like you have a great plan to foster connection and openness within the GroupMe. Sharing your experiences and encouraging others to open up could really make a difference. As you move forward, what might be some challenges you anticipate, and how could you address them? Perhaps we can brainstorm some strategies together.

I guess one challenge could be getting people to actually respond and engage. Like, people might join but not participate. I might need to come up with ways to keep things active, maybe by posting regularly or having themed days or something. I also worry about balancing everything if it grows too quickly, but I guess that's a good problem to have.

Therapist: You've really thought this through, and it's impressive how proactive and inclusive your approach is. Recognizing that participation might be a challenge shows your insight and readiness to adapt. Regular posts and themed days sound like great ideas to keep the group lively and engaging. As for balancing everything, perhaps setting some boundaries for yourself about the time you dedicate could help maintain that balance. You've got a solid plan, and it's great to see your enthusiasm and leadership. Remember, it's okay to take it one step at a time. You've got this, and I'm here to support you along the way. Let's check in next session to see how things are unfolding and explore any new ideas or adjustments you might consider.
Thanks for the support! I'll definitely try to set some boundaries and see how things go. Looking forward to our next chat to share updates.
